p: Myxoma virus (MYXV) belongs to the Poxviridae family and the Leporipoxvirus genus. In Spain, myxomatosis was first diagnosed in domestic rabbits towards the end of 1953 [ 13]. There were outbreaks of classic or typical myxomatosis until 1978, with different degrees of cutaneous clinical expression in the form of pseudotumors: myxomas [ 7], depending on the susceptibility of the rabbits and viral strains involved [ 14]. From 1979 onwards, the presence of atypical myxomatosis was described “with decreased cutaneous expression and continued respiratory problems” [ 7]. Since then, outbreaks of both forms have occurred: classic and atypical or “amyxomatous”, mistakenly referred to as “respiratory” [ 15]. In a previous study, based on 660 visited farms, we reported a seasonal variation with an increase from October to December [ 16].
